description: This mock EHR dataset mimics an ONC‑certified system with comprehensive patient data and an insurance education module. It contains ten synthetic patient profiles representing a broad range of coverage types (Original Medicare, Medicare Advantage HMO, Medicaid managed care, employer HMO, marketplace PPO, EPO, uninsured, charity care, dual‑eligible ACO, and capitated integrated system). Each patient record includes vital signs, medications, allergies, lab results, clinic visits, imaging reports, hospital admissions/discharges, insurance details, reimbursement model and a history of claims. Fifty interactive learning cases are provided to teach medical students how to navigate insurance processes. Each case references a patient, describes a realistic scenario, specifies tasks learners must perform in the EHR, provides the expected outcome, and states the learning objective. The insurance concepts are grounded in authoritative sources on insurance coverage, cost‑sharing and plan types【363281853880941†L21-L30】【456500307500387†L72-L100】.

insurance.planType: Original Medicare with Part A, Part B, Part D and Medigap Plan G
insurance.coverageDetails: Original Medicare covers inpatient services under Part A and outpatient/physician services under Part B; John has a Part D prescription plan and a Medigap Plan G that pays the Part A deductible and the 20% coinsurance on Part B services【24†L120-L128】. This fee‑for‑service structure means providers bill for each service rendered and Medicare pays according to the fee schedule【24†L138-L142】.

claimsHistory.notes: Medicare paid DRG rate and Medigap covered Part A deductible【24†L120-L128】.
Medicare paid 80% and Medigap paid 20% coinsurance【24†L138-L142】.
Initial denial due to missing diagnosis code; resubmitted with appropriate diagnosis and paid in full.
Part D plan required prior authorization; after approval, plan paid and patient paid specialty tier copay.

hospital.outcome: Observation stay; final claim pending determination of inpatient vs outpatient status

insurance.coverageDetails: Mary is enrolled in a Medicare Advantage HMO plan that combines Part A, Part B and Part D coverage. The plan requires that she use an in‑network primary care physician and obtain referrals for specialist care【19†L86-L94】. Copays are $20 for primary care and $50 for specialist visits, with a $300 deductible for hospital services. The plan uses capitation for primary care and a fee‑for‑service schedule for specialists【22†L52-L56】.

claimsHistory.notes: Covered under capitation; patient pays $20 copay.
Referral was on file; plan paid allowed amount minus specialist copay.
Denied due to missing prior authorization; allowed after appeal【40†L35-L40】.
Awaiting determination of inpatient vs outpatient classification and coverage.
Tier‑1 generic drug copay.

patients.name: Angela Rodriguez
patients.address: 789 Pine Street, Capital City, TX, USA

insurance.coverageDetails: Angela is enrolled in a Medicaid managed care plan. There are no deductibles and only nominal copays for visits and medications; the state pays a per‑member per‑month capitated amount to the MCO【22†L52-L56】. Emergency services and preventive care are covered without cost‑sharing. Authorization is required for some specialist services and certain brand‑name drugs.

claimsHistory.notes: Emergency services fully covered; no cost to patient.
Covered under capitation; no copay for Medicaid adult visit.
Denied for incorrect code; resubmitted with valid CPT and paid.
Requires prior authorization; decision pending.
Nominal copay per Medicaid formulary rules.

insurance.coverageDetails: David’s HMO plan requires using in‑network providers within the local network and obtaining a referral from his primary care physician for specialist visits【19†L86-L94】. The annual deductible is $500; copays are $20 for primary care and $40 for specialists. No out‑of‑network coverage except in emergencies, and preventive services are covered without cost‑sharing.
insurance.reimbursementModel: Capitation for primary care; fee‑for‑service for specialists

claimsHistory.notes: Preventive service fully covered as mandated by the ACA.
Specialist copay applied after referral confirmed.
Non‑emergency out‑of‑network care not covered by HMO【19†L94-L97】.
Requires prior authorization; review in process.
Covered medication with pharmacy copay.

imaging.result: Performed at out‑of‑network facility; high cost

insurance.coverageDetails: Susan purchased a PPO plan on the exchange with a $1,500 deductible and 20% coinsurance in‑network and 40% coinsurance out‑of‑network【18†L123-L131】. Copays of $30 for primary care and $50 for specialists apply before the deductible. Preventive services are covered without cost‑sharing. Out‑of‑network providers may balance bill the difference between charged and allowed amounts【18†L92-L100】.

claimsHistory.notes: Applied to deductible; patient pays full allowed amount until deductible met【12†L23-L31】.
40% coinsurance plus balance billing; out‑of‑network provider charged above allowed amount【18†L123-L131】.
Exceeded benefit limit for chiropractic services; non‑covered service.
After deductible met, 20% coinsurance applied【12†L33-L40】.
Covered after deductible; 20% coinsurance.

insurance.coverageDetails: Michael’s EPO plan has a $2,000 deductible and 10% coinsurance for in‑network services. Out‑of‑network care is not covered except for true emergencies【19†L94-L97】. Preventive care is fully covered. Specialist referrals are not required for in‑network providers【18†L98-L102】.

claimsHistory.notes: Emergency out‑of‑network care treated as in‑network; patient met deductible and out‑of‑pocket max and then plan paid 100%【11†L307-L315】.
After out‑of‑pocket max met, plan pays 100%.
Out‑of‑pocket max already reached; $0 owed.
Non‑emergency out‑of‑network care not covered by EPO【19†L94-L97】.
Preventive visit covered after meeting out‑of‑pocket max.

clinicVisits.reason: Blood pressure check at free clinic
clinicVisits.outcome: Blood pressure elevated; referred for follow‑up

insurance.coverageDetails: James has no insurance coverage. He is responsible for the full charges of care but qualifies for hospital charity care or sliding‑scale clinic fees depending on income【15†L27-L35】【16†L126-L134】. In some states, uninsured patients receive discounts off hospital charges.

claimsHistory.notes: Hospital wrote off 100% of the bill as charity care due to low income【16†L126-L134】.
Clinic charges based on sliding fee scale; patient paid nominal fee.
Patient received a cash discount by paying upfront.
Purchased using a drug discount program.
Unpaid bill sent to collections; reflects financial challenges for uninsured patients.

insurance.coverageDetails: Latoya is uninsured but approved for her hospital’s financial assistance program. Medically necessary services at the hospital and its clinics are fully discounted under the charity policy【16†L126-L134】. She relies on manufacturer patient assistance for medications. There is no deductible, premium or copay for charity-covered services.

claimsHistory.notes: Hospital wrote off the entire charge under its charity policy.
Covered by financial assistance; no bill to patient.
ER charges fully waived under charity care program.
Medication provided through manufacturer assistance program.
Hospital covered this specialist visit at no cost.

insurance.planType: Dual eligible (Original Medicare primary, Medicaid secondary)
insurance.coverageDetails: Robert is covered by Original Medicare for hospital and medical services and also has Medicaid as secondary payer (dual eligible). He is cared for within an Accountable Care Organization (ACO) participating in Medicare’s Shared Savings Program【21†L323-L331】【21†L333-L339】. Medicaid pays his deductibles and coinsurance, so he has minimal out‑of‑pocket costs.

claimsHistory.notes: Medicare paid DRG rate; Medicaid covered Part A deductible. ACO monitors readmission rates【21†L323-L331】.
Paid by Medicare Part B; part of value‑based care plan.
Monthly care coordination payment; Medicaid covers coinsurance.
Paid by Medicare and Medicaid; flagged for quality review to reduce avoidable utilization.
Medicare covered; Medicaid paid remaining coinsurance.

hospital.outcome: Vaginal delivery; healthy mother and child

insurance.coverageDetails: Aisha’s employer plan is part of an integrated health system similar to Kaiser. She pays no deductible and $20 copays for visits, with a $200 inpatient copay. Care must be received within the system’s network. The system receives a per‑member per‑month capitated payment to cover her care and uses internal budgeting for services.

claimsHistory.notes: Covered under global maternity bundle; patient paid $200 hospital copay.
Covered within capitated budget; patient paid only $200 copay for admission.
Preventive pediatric visits covered without cost.
Specialist visit within system; copay applies but no claim to external insurer.
Covered under pharmacy benefit with tiered copay.

cases.title: New Patient Insurance Verification
cases.scenario: Mary Smith arrives for her first appointment. The learner must verify her Medicare Advantage HMO coverage and identify referral requirements.
tasks: Open Mary’s insurance details in the EHR.
Confirm that her HMO plan is active and identify her assigned primary care physician.
Determine whether referrals are required for specialist visits and document this.
cases.expectedOutcome: The learner confirms the plan is active, sees that Mary has an HMO requiring a primary care physician and referrals for specialists【19†L86-L94】, and documents these requirements.
cases.learningObjective: Demonstrate the ability to verify insurance eligibility and understand HMO network/referral rules.

cases.title: Medicaid Eligibility Check
cases.scenario: Angela arrives at the clinic. The learner must confirm that her Medicaid managed care coverage is active on the service date.
tasks: Access Angela’s Coverage record in the EHR.
Verify the Medicaid plan’s effective dates.
Document whether any copay applies for today’s visit.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner finds Angela’s Medicaid coverage is active and notes that there is no copay for the visit since Medicaid typically waives cost‑sharing【22†L52-L56】.
cases.learningObjective: Practice verifying Medicaid eligibility and understanding Medicaid cost‑sharing policies.

cases.title: Dual Coverage Coordination
cases.scenario: Robert Chen presents with Medicare and Medicaid coverage. The learner must coordinate benefits by determining which coverage is primary.
tasks: Review Robert’s Coverage resources to identify the primary and secondary payers.
Determine which payer is billed first for today’s service.
Note how deductibles and coinsurance are handled.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner identifies that Medicare is primary and Medicaid is secondary for Robert (dual‑eligible). Claims should be submitted to Medicare first, then any remaining amount to Medicaid; deductibles and coinsurance are covered by Medicaid【14†L81-L89】.
cases.learningObjective: Understand coordination of benefits for dual‑eligible patients.

cases.title: Out‑of‑Network vs In‑Network Check
cases.scenario: Susan wants to see an out‑of‑network specialist. The learner must assess network status and advise on cost implications under her PPO plan.
tasks: Check the specialist’s network status in the insurance directory.
Determine Susan’s cost sharing for an out‑of‑network visit under her plan.
Explain potential balance billing to the patient.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner identifies the provider is out of network; under Susan’s PPO she will have 40% coinsurance and possible balance billing【18†L123-L131】. They document the high out‑of‑network cost and counsel the patient about potential extra charges【18†L92-L100】.
cases.learningObjective: Compare in‑network and out‑of‑network coverage rules and communicate cost differences to patients.

cases.title: Charity Care Eligibility Screening
cases.scenario: James needs an elective procedure but has no insurance. The learner must determine whether he qualifies for the hospital’s charity program.
tasks: Review James’s financial information in the EHR.
Check the hospital’s charity care eligibility criteria.
Document whether James qualifies and begin the application process if appropriate.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner finds that James’s income meets the criteria for charity care【16†L126-L134】 and initiates the financial assistance application, noting that charity care can write off his charges.
cases.learningObjective: Identify uninsured patients who may qualify for charity care and start the assistance process.

cases.title: Medicare Part Identification
cases.scenario: John hands you his Medicare card. The learner must document his Part A and Part B entitlement and determine if he has a Part D drug plan.
tasks: Locate John’s Medicare Coverage information.
Confirm effective dates for Part A and Part B.
Check for a Part D plan and document it.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner notes that Part A covers hospital services and Part B covers outpatient care【14†L21-L29】; John also has a Part D drug plan and Medigap. They document this in the chart.
cases.learningObjective: Recognize Medicare coverage parts and accurately enter them into the EHR.

cases.title: Office Visit Copay vs Coinsurance
cases.scenario: David has an office visit under his HMO. The learner must compute his out‑of‑pocket cost and differentiate between copay and coinsurance.
tasks: Review the allowed amount for David’s visit.
Identify his plan’s copay amount for a specialist visit.
Calculate his responsibility and document the difference between a flat copay and coinsurance.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner sees that the specialist visit has a $40 copay; since David’s plan uses copays rather than coinsurance for visits, he pays $40 and the plan covers the remainder【12†L54-L62】.
cases.learningObjective: Calculate patient cost using copays and explain how copays differ from coinsurance.

cases.title: Deductible Application (PPO Plan)
cases.scenario: Susan has her first orthopedic visit of the year and has not met her deductible. The learner must calculate how much she owes.
tasks: Check Susan’s remaining deductible for the year.
Determine the allowed amount for the visit.
Compute the patient’s payment and update the deductible balance.
cases.expectedOutcome: The visit cost of $200 is applied to her $1,500 deductible; Susan pays the full $200 because she hasn’t met her deductible yet【12†L23-L31】.
cases.learningObjective: Apply deductibles to patient bills and update cost‑sharing information.

cases.title: Coinsurance Calculation After Deductible
cases.scenario: Later in the year, Susan needs an in‑network MRI after meeting her deductible. The learner calculates coinsurance.
tasks: Confirm that Susan’s deductible is met.
Determine the allowed amount for the MRI.
Calculate the 20% coinsurance amount and patient payment.
cases.expectedOutcome: Since the $1,500 deductible is already met, Susan pays 20% of the allowed amount (e.g., $1,000 MRI → $200 coinsurance) and the insurer pays 80%【12†L33-L40】.
cases.learningObjective: Compute coinsurance amounts once the deductible is satisfied.

cases.title: Out‑of‑Pocket Maximum Scenario
cases.scenario: Michael’s appendectomy has led to large expenses. The learner must determine when his out‑of‑pocket maximum is reached and how that affects subsequent services.
tasks: Review Michael’s claims to see his cumulative payments toward the deductible and coinsurance.
Identify the out‑of‑pocket maximum on his EPO plan.
Determine when the max was met and explain how costs are covered thereafter.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner observes that after paying $6,000 (deductible plus coinsurance) Michael met his out‑of‑pocket max; the EPO covers 100% of additional covered costs for the rest of the year【11†L307-L315】.
cases.learningObjective: Understand the role of out‑of‑pocket maximums in limiting patient liability.

cases.title: Insurance Year Reset
cases.scenario: It’s a new calendar year. Mary returns for a specialist visit. The learner must explain how deductibles reset annually.
tasks: Check Mary’s deductible accumulation for the new year.
Determine whether any deductible remains from the previous year.
Explain to Mary why she must meet a new deductible this year.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner sees that Mary’s $300 deductible resets on January 1; she has paid $0 toward it this year, so she must pay the deductible on her next hospital service. The learner explains that deductibles restart annually.
cases.learningObjective: Communicate how annual deductibles reset and affect patient costs.

cases.title: ER Visit Cost‑Sharing (Medicaid vs Private)
cases.scenario: Compare ER visits for Angela (Medicaid) and David (private HMO) to illustrate differences in cost sharing.
tasks: Review Angela’s ER claim and note patient cost.
Review David’s ER copay for a comparable visit.
Document the differences in patient responsibility.
cases.expectedOutcome: Angela’s ER visit is fully covered with no cost to her under Medicaid【22†L52-L56】, whereas David’s HMO charges a $200 ER copay. The learner documents this contrast.
cases.learningObjective: Highlight differences in cost sharing between Medicaid and commercial plans for emergency care.

cases.title: Pharmacy Benefit Tiering
cases.scenario: Mary fills two prescriptions: a tier 1 generic and a tier 3 brand drug. The learner must determine her payments.
tasks: Identify the tier for each medication in Mary’s plan.
Look up the copay or coinsurance for each tier.
Calculate Mary’s cost for both medications.
cases.expectedOutcome: Mary pays a $5 copay for the generic drug and a higher coinsurance (e.g., 33% of the $200 cost) for the non‑preferred brand【12†L54-L62】.
cases.learningObjective: Interpret pharmacy formulary tiers and calculate drug cost sharing.

cases.title: Preventive Service Billing
cases.scenario: David undergoes a preventive colonoscopy. The learner must ensure it is billed as preventive to avoid patient costs.
tasks: Review procedure coding to confirm it is listed as screening.
Check that no biopsy or diagnostic code is attached that would change billing.
Explain to David that screening colonoscopy is fully covered under preventive benefits.
cases.expectedOutcome: If the colonoscopy is properly coded as preventive screening, there is no patient cost; if coded diagnostic, cost sharing applies. The learner ensures correct preventive coding and explains to David.
cases.learningObjective: Ensure preventive services are coded correctly to avoid unnecessary patient charges.

cases.title: Surgery Estimate with Cost Sharing
cases.scenario: Susan is planning elective knee surgery in‑network. The learner must estimate her out‑of‑pocket cost based on remaining deductible and coinsurance.
tasks: Assess Susan’s remaining deductible and out‑of‑pocket maximum.
Estimate the allowed amount for the surgery.
Calculate her expected payment combining deductible and coinsurance.
cases.expectedOutcome: If Susan has $500 left on her $1,500 deductible and the surgery costs $5,000, she pays $500 plus 20% of the remaining $4,500 = $1,400; total $1,900, subject to her out‑of‑pocket maximum. The insurer pays the rest.
cases.learningObjective: Provide cost estimates for elective procedures using deductible and coinsurance rules.

cases.title: Balance Billing Issue
cases.scenario: Susan receives a surprise bill from an out‑of‑network anesthesiologist. The learner must identify balance billing and advise Susan.
tasks: Examine the EOB and bill to confirm it is from an out‑of‑network provider.
Compare the provider charge with the allowed amount.
Discuss with Susan the possibility of negotiating or appealing under the No Surprises Act if applicable.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner explains that the anesthesiologist is out‑of‑network and the difference between billed and allowed amounts constitutes balance billing; they advise Susan on negotiation or protections under surprise billing legislation.
cases.learningObjective: Identify balance billing scenarios and counsel patients on recourse options.

cases.title: Specialist Referral in HMO
cases.scenario: David wants to see a dermatologist. The learner must ensure a PCP referral is obtained.
tasks: Verify in David’s plan that a referral is required for dermatology.
Check if a referral is already on file.
Initiate a referral request from his PCP if needed.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner confirms that the HMO requires a referral; obtains a referral authorization and documents it, preventing claim denial【19†L86-L94】.
cases.learningObjective: Navigate referral requirements in an HMO to avoid claim denials.

cases.title: Imaging Prior Authorization
cases.scenario: Mary needs a high‑cost MRI. The learner must obtain prior authorization before scheduling.
tasks: Identify that MRI of the knee requires prior authorization in Mary’s plan.
Complete the authorization request with clinical justification.
Await approval before ordering the MRI.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner submits the prior authorization and avoids the denial experienced previously【40†L35-L40】.
cases.learningObjective: Understand prior authorization requirements and processes for expensive services.

cases.title: Medication Prior Authorization
cases.scenario: Angela’s physician prescribes a non‑formulary inhaler. The learner must obtain prior authorization.
tasks: Check Angela’s formulary and confirm the drug requires authorization.
Submit a prior authorization request with documentation of failed generic alternatives.
Follow up for approval before dispensing.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner submits a complete prior authorization demonstrating medical necessity for the non‑formulary inhaler and obtains approval.
cases.learningObjective: Perform medication prior authorization in accordance with plan rules.

cases.title: Elective Surgery Authorization
cases.scenario: Susan’s elective knee surgery requires pre‑certification. The learner must gather necessary information and submit the pre‑cert request.
tasks: Review the plan’s pre‑certification criteria for elective orthopedic surgery.
Collect supporting documentation (MRI results, physical therapy records).
Submit the pre‑cert request and follow up on approval.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner ensures pre‑certification is granted before surgery, avoiding denial of the claim.
cases.learningObjective: Ensure elective procedures meet pre‑certification requirements to secure coverage.

cases.title: Referral vs Direct Specialist Access
cases.scenario: Susan’s PPO allows direct specialist access. The learner must contrast this with HMO referral requirements.
tasks: Review Susan’s plan documents to confirm no referral is needed.
Schedule the specialist appointment directly.
Explain to Susan that PPOs allow self‑referral whereas HMOs require PCP referrals【19†L90-L97】.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner documents that Susan can see a specialist without a referral under her PPO plan and communicates the difference compared to HMO rules.
cases.learningObjective: Compare specialist access rules between PPO and HMO plans.

cases.title: Emergency vs Non‑Emergency Authorization
cases.scenario: Michael had emergency surgery without prior authorization. The learner must justify why this was covered and differentiate from elective cases.
tasks: Review the claim for the emergency appendectomy.
Identify plan policy on prior authorization for emergent vs elective procedures.
Document that emergencies do not require authorization while elective surgeries do.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner explains that true emergencies are exempt from prior authorization and the claim is covered; elective surgeries would need pre‑certification.
cases.learningObjective: Differentiate authorization requirements for emergency versus elective services.

cases.title: Therapy Services Authorization
cases.scenario: Angela needs more physical therapy sessions than automatically covered. The learner must request additional authorization.
tasks: Check Angela’s plan for the number of physical therapy visits covered without auth.
Document progress notes to justify more visits.
Submit an authorization request for the additional sessions.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner obtains authorization for extra therapy visits by demonstrating medical necessity and adherence to plan limits.
cases.learningObjective: Manage visit limits and obtain authorization for extended therapy services.

cases.title: Reading a Simple EOB
cases.scenario: John receives an Explanation of Benefits for an outpatient visit. The learner must interpret the EOB.
tasks: Open the ExplanationOfBenefit resource for John’s cardiology visit.
Identify the total charge, allowed amount, Medicare payment and Medigap payment.
Confirm patient responsibility.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner reads the EOB: $150 charged; Medicare allowed $150, paid 80% ($120) and Medigap paid 20% ($30); patient owes $0【2†L85-L93】.
cases.learningObjective: Develop the skill to interpret EOBs and understand the financial breakdown.

cases.title: EOB with Denial Reason
cases.scenario: Mary’s MRI claim was denied. The learner must read the EOB and identify the denial reason.
tasks: Access the ExplanationOfBenefit for the MRI.
Locate the adjudication section and read the denial code.
Document the reason and next steps.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner finds the denial code indicating that prior authorization was not obtained【40†L35-L40】 and notes that an appeal or corrected claim is required.
cases.learningObjective: Identify denial reasons on an EOB and plan corrective action.

cases.title: Inpatient Hospital EOB (Medicare)
cases.scenario: John receives a Medicare Summary Notice after his hospitalization. The learner must interpret this EOB.
tasks: Review the MSN/EOB for the hospital stay.
Identify the DRG payment amount and Part A deductible.
Determine the patient’s financial responsibility after Medigap.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner notes that Medicare paid a lump‑sum DRG rate (e.g., $7,500)【24†L120-L128】, the Part A deductible was covered by Medigap, and John owes $0.
cases.learningObjective: Interpret inpatient EOBs and understand DRG payments and supplemental coverage.

cases.title: Bundled Maternity EOB
cases.scenario: Aisha receives a single EOB for her prenatal, delivery and postpartum care. The learner must recognize bundling.
tasks: Open the EOB covering maternity services.
Note that multiple services are combined into a global maternity fee.
Determine patient responsibility (copay only).
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner observes that prenatal care, delivery and postpartum visits are bundled under a global fee; patient only paid a $200 copay and no separate line items【29†L25-L33】.
cases.learningObjective: Understand bundled payments and how they appear on EOBs.

cases.title: Pharmacy EOB/Part D Summary
cases.scenario: John receives a Part D EOB for his medications. The learner must analyze the document.
tasks: Review the drug costs, plan payments and patient copays.
Determine which phase of coverage John is in (deductible, initial, coverage gap or catastrophic).
Note how close he is to the coverage gap threshold.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner identifies drug costs, sees the Part D plan paid the bulk and John paid a $100 specialty copay; he is approaching the coverage gap. They document the stage and potential increased costs.
cases.learningObjective: Interpret Part D EOBs and monitor progress through coverage phases.

cases.title: EOB Error Investigation
cases.scenario: Susan spots an unfamiliar service on her EOB. The learner must investigate and correct potential billing errors.
tasks: Identify the questionable line item on Susan’s EOB.
Contact the provider’s billing office to verify whether the service was rendered.
Correct the claim or report possible fraud.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner confirms that the charge was a duplicate entry and requests the provider to submit a corrected claim, ensuring Susan is not billed in error.
cases.learningObjective: Detect and resolve billing errors by reviewing EOBs and working with providers.

cases.title: Patient Cost Comparison via EOBs
cases.scenario: The learner compares EOBs from Angela (Medicaid) and Susan (PPO) to illustrate differences in patient liability.
tasks: Compare similar services (e.g., office visits) on both EOBs.
Identify the payer and patient payment amounts.
Summarize differences in cost sharing.
cases.expectedOutcome: Medicaid EOB shows no patient liability for covered services【22†L52-L56】, whereas Susan’s EOB shows patient responsibility for deductible and coinsurance. The learner summarises the contrast.
cases.learningObjective: Analyze EOBs across plan types to understand how cost sharing affects patients.

cases.title: Choosing a Medicare Option
cases.scenario: Mary is turning 65 and deciding between Original Medicare plus Medigap and a Medicare Advantage plan. The learner must outline pros and cons.
tasks: Summarize the benefits and limitations of Original Medicare + Medigap (flexibility, higher premium, nationwide provider access).
Summarize the benefits and limitations of Medicare Advantage HMO (lower out‑of‑pocket costs, network restrictions, extra benefits).
Discuss Mary’s priorities (cost, provider choice, travel) and recommend an option.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner explains that Original Medicare with Medigap offers broad provider choice and supplemental coverage but higher premium, while Medicare Advantage has lower monthly cost but network restrictions【14†L69-L77】【14†L81-L89】; recommendation depends on Mary’s preferences.
cases.learningObjective: Compare Medicare enrollment options and advise patients based on their needs.

cases.title: Marketplace Plan Comparison
cases.scenario: Susan is selecting between Gold and Silver marketplace plans for next year. The learner must compare premiums, deductibles and expected costs.
tasks: Review plan summaries for Gold and Silver options (premiums, deductibles, coinsurance).
Estimate total annual cost based on Susan’s expected health care use.
Recommend a plan that balances premium and cost sharing.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner notes that Gold has higher premiums but lower deductible and coinsurance, which may save money given Susan’s frequent care; Silver has lower premiums but higher out‑of‑pocket costs. They provide a reasoned recommendation.
cases.learningObjective: Evaluate marketplace plan tiers to guide patient plan selection.

cases.title: HMO vs PPO Decision
cases.scenario: A patient similar to David is offered a choice between an HMO and PPO. The learner must explain differences and advise based on patient circumstances.
tasks: List HMO characteristics: lower cost, network restrictions, referral requirements【19†L86-L94】.
List PPO characteristics: higher cost, more flexibility, no referrals【19†L90-L97】.
Assess the patient’s needs (e.g., frequent travel, preferred doctor not in network) and recommend a plan.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner explains that HMO is cost‑effective for those staying in network, while PPO is better for those needing flexibility; they recommend based on the hypothetical patient’s circumstances.
cases.learningObjective: Compare HMO and PPO plans and advise patients accordingly.

cases.title: Medicaid vs Employer Insurance Coordination
cases.scenario: Angela gets a new job offering employer insurance while on Medicaid. The learner must coordinate her coverage.
tasks: Review eligibility criteria for Medicaid when income changes.
Determine whether employer coverage is primary and Medicaid becomes secondary.
Advise Angela on potential loss of Medicaid or coordination of benefits.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner explains that employer insurance becomes primary and Medicaid may act as secondary if she still qualifies; if income exceeds the threshold, Medicaid may terminate and employer plan becomes sole coverage.
cases.learningObjective: Coordinate benefits and counsel patients transitioning between Medicaid and employer insurance.

cases.title: Student Health Plan vs Parental Insurance
cases.scenario: A 20‑year‑old college student (example) can choose between the campus health plan and remaining on a parent’s insurance. The learner must compare options.
tasks: Review benefits and network for the campus plan.
Review benefits and network for the parent’s plan (e.g., PPO).
Consider costs, provider access near campus and coverage while traveling, then recommend.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner suggests staying on the parent’s comprehensive PPO if provider access is needed beyond campus; the campus plan may suffice if cost is lower and care is centralized, but may limit access off campus. They document pros and cons.
cases.learningObjective: Evaluate student health plans versus parental coverage to advise young adults.

cases.title: Insurance Plan Benefit Interpretation (HDHP vs HMO)
cases.scenario: Aisha is offered a high‑deductible health plan (HDHP) with HSA or staying with her current integrated plan. The learner must interpret the benefit differences.
tasks: Compare the HDHP: high deductible, lower premium, eligible for HSA.
Compare the capitated HMO: low/no deductible, higher premium, limited network.
Assess Aisha’s expected health care costs (e.g., pregnancy planning, chronic conditions) and recommend a plan.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner notes that an HDHP may benefit those with low expected costs who want to build an HSA, while the integrated HMO provides predictable costs and comprehensive care. For Aisha planning another pregnancy, the HMO may be better due to predictable costs.
cases.learningObjective: Interpret HDHP vs HMO benefits and help patients choose accordingly.

cases.title: Claim Denial – Missing Referral
cases.scenario: David’s dermatologist claim is denied because no referral was on file. The learner must address the denial.
tasks: Review the EOB to confirm denial reason (no referral).
Contact the PCP to request a retroactive referral if possible.
Resubmit the claim with referral documentation or advise patient on appeal.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner confirms the denial code, obtains a retroactive referral from the PCP and resubmits the claim; if retro authorization is not accepted, they advise David that the claim may remain denied.
cases.learningObjective: Resolve denials related to missing referrals in HMO plans.

cases.title: Claim Denial – Not Medically Necessary
cases.scenario: Mary’s brand drug claim is denied as not medically necessary. The learner must appeal.
tasks: Review the plan’s medical necessity criteria and alternative drug options.
Gather clinical evidence of Mary’s failure on generic medications.
Draft and submit an appeal citing medical necessity.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner submits a detailed appeal documenting why the brand drug is necessary (previous generic failure) and obtains authorization for coverage.
cases.learningObjective: Develop skills to appeal medical necessity denials using clinical evidence.

cases.title: Claim Denial – Coding Error
cases.scenario: Angela’s therapy claim is denied for invalid coding. The learner must correct it.
tasks: Identify the incorrect code on the claim.
Determine the correct CPT code for the service.
Resubmit the corrected claim.
cases.expectedOutcome: The learner identifies the wrong code, corrects it and resubmits; the claim is paid upon correction.
cases.learningObjective: Ensure accurate coding to prevent claim denials.

cases.title: Denied Hospital Claim – Observation vs Inpatient Status
cases.scenario: Mary’s overnight stay was billed as inpatient but denied; the learner must determine appropriate status.
tasks: Review medical records and admission criteria for inpatient status.
Determine if the stay should be billed as observation (outpatient).
Either rebill as observation or appeal the denial if inpatient criteria were met.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner concludes that Mary’s 1‑night stay did not meet inpatient criteria and rebills as observation, resulting in payment under Part B; or, if criteria met, they appeal the denial.
cases.learningObjective: Assess inpatient vs observation status to avoid denials.

cases.title: Surgery Pre‑Auth Denial
cases.scenario: Susan’s surgery claim is denied because the pre‑authorization number was missing. The learner must resolve it.
tasks: Verify the denial reason on the EOB (missing pre‑auth).
Contact the insurer to see if retro authorization is possible.
Submit the missing number or appeal based on medical necessity.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner provides the pre‑auth number and resubmits the claim; if not accepted, they appeal or negotiate coverage. They document the result.
cases.learningObjective: Respond to pre‑auth denials and salvage coverage where possible.

cases.title: Appeal Process Education
cases.scenario: Mary’s MRI denial leads to a teaching opportunity. The learner must draft an appeal letter.
tasks: Outline the steps of appealing to the insurer (initial appeal, external review).
Draft a letter including patient info, service details, and reasons for overturning the denial.
Submit the appeal through the appropriate channel.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner produces a professional appeal letter citing Mary’s need for the MRI and referencing plan policy; they submit it to the insurer for reconsideration.
cases.learningObjective: Practice the procedural steps and format for appealing a denied claim.

cases.title: Denied Claim – Patient Eligibility Lapse
cases.scenario: John has a claim denied because his insurance shows inactive on the date of service. The learner must investigate and resolve.
tasks: Check if John’s Medicare coverage lapsed or if there was an administrative error.
Contact Medicare to verify eligibility on the service date.
If coverage is active, resubmit with proof; if not, counsel the patient on options.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner discovers the denial was due to an eligibility verification error; Medicare confirms coverage was active, and the claim is resubmitted and paid.
cases.learningObjective: Handle denials related to eligibility lapses and correct administrative errors.

cases.title: Tracking Appeals and Resolutions
cases.scenario: Multiple appeals are underway for Mary and other patients. The learner must manage the worklist.
tasks: Open the appeals worklist in the EHR.
Update the status of each appeal (submitted, awaiting response, resolved).
Note deadlines for insurer responses and plan follow‑up actions.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner organizes appeals, ensuring timely follow‑up and documenting outcomes; they note that Mary’s MRI appeal is pending, the surgery appeal is approved, and others are in progress.
cases.learningObjective: Develop skills in managing multiple insurance appeals efficiently.

cases.title: Self‑Pay Cost Estimate & Payment Plan
cases.scenario: James needs a non‑urgent imaging test. The learner must provide a self‑pay estimate and set up a payment plan.
tasks: Identify the list price for the imaging test.
Apply the hospital’s uninsured discount (e.g., 40%) to determine the self‑pay amount.
Work with James to establish a monthly payment plan and document the agreement.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner calculates the discounted price (e.g., $500 list → $300 after discount) and sets up a plan for James to pay $50/month for 6 months, documenting terms.
cases.learningObjective: Counsel uninsured patients on cost estimates and create payment plans.

cases.title: Sliding Scale Clinic Workflow
cases.scenario: At a community clinic, James’s fee is determined by a sliding scale. The learner must apply the scale.
tasks: Review James’s income documentation.
Consult the clinic’s sliding fee scale to determine his percentage.
Calculate the patient charge for today’s visit and collect payment.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner determines James falls in the 20% tier; for a $100 visit, he pays $20. This is documented and collected.
cases.learningObjective: Apply sliding fee scales to determine patient charges for uninsured patients.

cases.title: Enrollment in Coverage Programs
cases.scenario: Latoya is applying for Medicaid or marketplace coverage. The learner must help her enroll in an insurance program to reduce reliance on charity care.
tasks: Assess Latoya’s income and household size to determine Medicaid eligibility.
If eligible, assist with a Medicaid application; if not, explore marketplace plans with subsidies.
Provide information on enrollment deadlines and premiums.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner determines that Latoya qualifies for Medicaid based on income and helps her submit the application. If not, they assist with selecting an affordable subsidized marketplace plan.
cases.learningObjective: Facilitate insurance enrollment for uninsured/underinsured patients.

cases.title: Handling a Large Bill (Ethical Scenario)
cases.scenario: James receives a $100,000 ICU bill. The learner must explore options to reduce the burden.
tasks: Review the itemized bill to understand the charges.
Check if James qualifies for retroactive Medicaid coverage or additional charity care.
Negotiate with the hospital or advise on legal protections (e.g., inability to pay).
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner considers applying for retroactive Medicaid (covers up to 3 months prior)【14†L81-L89】, or additional charity care to write off the bill; they engage the hospital’s financial assistance office to reduce or eliminate the debt.
cases.learningObjective: Navigate ethical and financial options for patients facing catastrophic medical bills.

cases.title: Point‑of‑Service Payment Policy
cases.scenario: Aisha seeks a cosmetic procedure not covered by insurance. The learner must explain self‑payment and obtain consent.
tasks: Confirm that the procedure is elective and not covered by Aisha’s plan.
Provide a cost estimate for the procedure.
Obtain signed consent acknowledging the patient is responsible for full payment.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner informs Aisha that cosmetic services are excluded; she must pay out of pocket before scheduling. They document the discussion and obtain consent.
cases.learningObjective: Counsel patients on non‑covered services and handle self‑pay consent.

cases.title: Financial Assistance Renewal
cases.scenario: Latoya’s charity care eligibility is expiring. The learner must help her renew to maintain coverage.
tasks: Review the expiration date of Latoya’s current financial assistance approval.
Gather updated income documentation from Latoya.
Submit a renewal application before the deadline.
cases.expectedOutcome: Learner ensures Latoya’s financial assistance is renewed for another year by submitting updated documents; if she fails to renew, the EHR will revert her to self‑pay status.
cases.learningObjective: Manage ongoing financial assistance programs and prevent lapses.
